filename: EMA - Abstract 8_ Adherence to _Choosing Wisely_ Recommendations in Pediatric Care - EMA 2025 June _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: The Choosing Wisely campaign has targeted several 'low-value' tests in a variety of fields.

filename: EMA - Abstract 8_ Adherence to _Choosing Wisely_ Recommendations in Pediatric Care - EMA 2025 June _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: In 2022, 5 diagnostic tests relevant to pediatric emergency medicine were identified as targets for the Choosing Wisely campaign: (1) x-rays for respiratory tract infections, (2) laboratory screening for psychiatric medical clearance, (3) laboratory testing or head CT for unprovoked generalized seizures or simple febrile seizures with return to baseline mental status, (4) abdominal radiographs for suspected constipation, and (5) comprehensive viral panels for suspected respiratory viral illness.

filename: EMA - Abstract 8_ Adherence to _Choosing Wisely_ Recommendations in Pediatric Care - EMA 2025 June _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: The aim of this study was to determine how often these low-value tests are performed.

filename: EMA - Abstract 8_ Adherence to _Choosing Wisely_ Recommendations in Pediatric Care - EMA 2025 June _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: The study used emergency department data from 8 states from 2014 to 2020.

filename: EMA - Abstract 8_ Adherence to _Choosing Wisely_ Recommendations in Pediatric Care - EMA 2025 June _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: Importantly, the data came from administrative/billing data rather than any form of clinical chart review.

filename: EMA - Abstract 8_ Adherence to _Choosing Wisely_ Recommendations in Pediatric Care - EMA 2025 June _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: Children <18 years of age were included if they had 1 of the aforementioned diagnostic codes and were excluded under certain circumstances.

filename: EMA - Abstract 8_ Adherence to _Choosing Wisely_ Recommendations in Pediatric Care - EMA 2025 June _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: For example, a diagnosis code of generalized seizure would have led to inclusion, but a concurrent diagnosis of trauma or age <180 days would have led to exclusion.

filename: EMA - Abstract 8_ Adherence to _Choosing Wisely_ Recommendations in Pediatric Care - EMA 2025 June _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: During the study period, 6,778,296 visits for the conditions of interest were recorded across participating states.

filename: EMA - Abstract 8_ Adherence to _Choosing Wisely_ Recommendations in Pediatric Care - EMA 2025 June _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: After application of the exclusion criteria, 5,628,276 visits were included in the analysis.

filename: EMA - Abstract 8_ Adherence to _Choosing Wisely_ Recommendations in Pediatric Care - EMA 2025 June _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: Low-value testing occurred in 1,088,845 (19.3%) visits, including 31% of respiratory illness visits, 17% of mental or behavioral visits, 43% of seizure visits, 66% of constipation visits, and 3% of respiratory viral illness visits.

filename: EMA - Abstract 8_ Adherence to _Choosing Wisely_ Recommendations in Pediatric Care - EMA 2025 June _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: No consistent relationship was observed between the proportion of visits with a low-value test performed and the volume of pediatric cases in the EDs.

filename: EMA - Abstract 8_ Adherence to _Choosing Wisely_ Recommendations in Pediatric Care - EMA 2025 June _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: Temporal analysis indicated that the rates of testing for these conditions were fairly consistent from 2014 to 2020, except for viral respiratory panel testing, which increased.

sentence: The authors propose benchmark testing levels based on the top performing 10% of hospitals (4% for chest x-ray in respiratory illness, 0% for laboratory testing in mental health cases, 8% for seizures, 16% for constipation, and 0% for viral panel testing).

sentence: In a simple example, for respiratory tract infections, if a chest x-ray had been performed and indicated pneumonia, the child would have been diagnosed with pneumonia and not included in this cohort.

sentence: Most of the biases would have inflated the estimate of low-value testing.

filename: EMA - Abstract 17_ Benefit of AI-Based Fracture Detection in a Pediatric ED - EMA 2025 July _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: Reading pediatric plain films is challenging, because the fracture patterns markedly differ from those in adults: in children, normal architecture can appear as avulsions, and growth plates can mimic fracture lines.

filename: EMA - Abstract 17_ Benefit of AI-Based Fracture Detection in a Pediatric ED - EMA 2025 July _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: The clinical consequences of missed fractures in children are often severe and may potentially result in long-term complications, such as restricted joint mobility or impaired growth, as well as substantial medicolegal implications.

filename: EMA - Abstract 17_ Benefit of AI-Based Fracture Detection in a Pediatric ED - EMA 2025 July _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: RBFracture is an AI software explicitly trained on children's x-rays to detect fractures.

filename: EMA - Abstract 17_ Benefit of AI-Based Fracture Detection in a Pediatric ED - EMA 2025 July _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: In this prospective study, the authors evaluated RBFracture's standalone performance in a pediatric 'real-life' cohort and in a set of selected medicolegally relevant fractures.

filename: EMA - Abstract 17_ Benefit of AI-Based Fracture Detection in a Pediatric ED - EMA 2025 July _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: In addition, they evaluated the influence of AI assistance on the diagnostic performance of inexperienced residents in (1) a 'real-life' cohort, comprising a consecutive sample of 1,672 x-rays obtained over a 6-month period for trauma at a single pediatric ED in Germany and (2) a medicolegal cohort comprising a separate set of radiographs from children with 1 of 3 pediatric-specific fracture types, which were retrospectively identified from the institutional radiological information system from 2008 to 2023.

filename: EMA - Abstract 17_ Benefit of AI-Based Fracture Detection in a Pediatric ED - EMA 2025 July _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: All films were read by the AI, 3 residents (2 in surgery and 1 in radiology), and attending physicians.

filename: EMA - Abstract 17_ Benefit of AI-Based Fracture Detection in a Pediatric ED - EMA 2025 July _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: Follow-up imaging and clinical follow-up served as the gold standard.

filename: EMA - Abstract 17_ Benefit of AI-Based Fracture Detection in a Pediatric ED - EMA 2025 July _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: In the cohort (median patient age, 10.9 years; 59% boys), the AI demonstrated an overall sensitivity of 92%, specificity of 83%, and accuracy of 87%.

filename: EMA - Abstract 17_ Benefit of AI-Based Fracture Detection in a Pediatric ED - EMA 2025 July _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: However, the individual test characteristics markedly varied across body regions.

filename: EMA - Abstract 17_ Benefit of AI-Based Fracture Detection in a Pediatric ED - EMA 2025 July _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: For example, the foot and ankle had a relatively low accuracy of 80%.

filename: EMA - Abstract 17_ Benefit of AI-Based Fracture Detection in a Pediatric ED - EMA 2025 July _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: For medicolegally relevant fractures, the test characteristics showed even greater variation across fracture types: the AI achieved a sensitivity of 100% for proximal tibia fractures but only 68% for radial condyle fractures.

filename: EMA - Abstract 17_ Benefit of AI-Based Fracture Detection in a Pediatric ED - EMA 2025 July _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: AI assistance increased the residents' sensitivity from 84% to 87%, specificity from 91% to 92%, and diagnostic accuracy from 88% to 90%.

filename: EMA - Abstract 17_ Benefit of AI-Based Fracture Detection in a Pediatric ED - EMA 2025 July _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: However, in 1.5% of cases, the residents erroneously changed their initially correct diagnoses after receiving the AI interpretation.

filename: EMA - Abstract 17_ Benefit of AI-Based Fracture Detection in a Pediatric ED - EMA 2025 July _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: No significant difference was observed between first-year pediatric surgical and radiology residents ( P <.05).

filename: EMA - Abstract 17_ Benefit of AI-Based Fracture Detection in a Pediatric ED - EMA 2025 July _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: The study's strength is in its large sample size (1,672 radiographs) and use of a pragmatic reallife cohort rather than artificially stratified samples.

filename: EMA - Abstract 17_ Benefit of AI-Based Fracture Detection in a Pediatric ED - EMA 2025 July _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: One limitation is that the providers were residents, and how having the AI reads might have influenced the confidence or accuracy of more seasoned providers is unknown.

filename: EMA - Abstract 17_ Benefit of AI-Based Fracture Detection in a Pediatric ED - EMA 2025 July _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: Overall, the influence of the study might be quite high, because some EDs are already using AI to aid in reading x-rays.

filename: EMA - Abstract 17_ Benefit of AI-Based Fracture Detection in a Pediatric ED - EMA 2025 July _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: Consequently, awareness of the potential effects on real-world practice is important.

filename: EMA - Abstract 17_ Benefit of AI-Based Fracture Detection in a Pediatric ED - EMA 2025 July _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: Overall, the authors conclude that, although the technology shows promise by providing "a second set of eyes," emergency departments would need to carefully weigh the modest accuracy gains against the implementation costs.

filename: EMA - Time to Talk a Little Nerdy_ Network Meta-Analysis - EMA 2025 July _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: In this episode of "Time to Talk a Little Nerdy," Ken and Swami break down Network Meta-Analysis (NMA) - a powerful statistical tool that lets researchers compare multiple treatments at once, even when they haven't been directly tested against each other.

filename: EMA - Time to Talk a Little Nerdy_ Network Meta-Analysis - EMA 2025 July _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: They explain how NMAs work, their benefits over traditional meta-analyses, and their limitations.

filename: EMA - Time to Talk a Little Nerdy_ Network Meta-Analysis - EMA 2025 July _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: Plus, they look at a real-world example

filename: EMA - Time to Talk a Little Nerdy_ Network Meta-Analysis - EMA 2025 July _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: comparing fever treatments for kids. If you've ever wondered how doctors figure out which treatment is best when there's no direct comparison, this episode is for you!

filename: EMA - Time to Talk a Little Nerdy_ Network Meta-Analysis - EMA 2025 July _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: Time to Talk a Little Nerdy

filename: EMA - Time to Talk a Little Nerdy_ Network Meta-Analysis - EMA 2025 July _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: Network Meta-Analysis

filename: EMA - Time to Talk a Little Nerdy_ Network Meta-Analysis - EMA 2025 July _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: This month, we are tackling a request from our executive producer, EJ Barnes.

filename: EMA - Time to Talk a Little Nerdy_ Network Meta-Analysis - EMA 2025 July _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: She noted that Mike and Sanjay have discussed a couple of network meta-analyses (NMAs) in the past year, and that we should discuss a bit about what an NMA is.

filename: EMA - Time to Talk a Little Nerdy_ Network Meta-Analysis - EMA 2025 July _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: Way back in December 2020, on Time to Talk a Little Nerdy, we got deep into systematic reviews and meta-analyses (SRMAs).

filename: EMA - Time to Talk a Little Nerdy_ Network Meta-Analysis - EMA 2025 July _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: Folks should pop back and check that discussion out.

filename: EMA - Time to Talk a Little Nerdy_ Network Meta-Analysis - EMA 2025 July _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: In brief, the benefit of SRMAs is that they can synthesize vast amounts of data to help inform clinical decision-making.

filename: EMA - Time to Talk a Little Nerdy_ Network Meta-Analysis - EMA 2025 July _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: A good SRMA follows the Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses (PRISMA) guidelines, and rigorously collects and evaluates multiple studies on a given topic.[1] SRMAs provide a structured way to summarize the evidence without a need to read each study on the topic.

filename: EMA - Time to Talk a Little Nerdy_ Network Meta-Analysis - EMA 2025 July _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: Thus, a well-conducted systematic review must follow rigorous methodological criteria, including comprehensive literature searches, risk-of-bias assessments, and appropriate statistical analyses, to ensure credible and meaningful results

filename: EMA - Time to Talk a Little Nerdy_ Network Meta-Analysis - EMA 2025 July _ EM_RAP.pdf
EMA - Time to Talk a Little Nerdy_ Network Meta-Analysis - EMA 2025 July _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: We do need to recognize the limitations of SRMAs.

filename: EMA - Time to Talk a Little Nerdy_ Network Meta-Analysis - EMA 2025 July _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: If the primary studies included have methodological flaws, these flaws can be propagated and magnified in the meta-analysis  .

filename: EMA - Time to Talk a Little Nerdy_ Network Meta-Analysis - EMA 2025 July _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: This phenomenon is called 'garbage in, garbage out' (GIGO).

filename: EMA - Time to Talk a Little Nerdy_ Network Meta-Analysis - EMA 2025 July _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: A few well-done randomized controlled trials (RCTs) on a topic can be superior to a poorly done SRMA that contains only observational data.

filename: EMA - Time to Talk a Little Nerdy_ Network Meta-Analysis - EMA 2025 July _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: An NMA is an advanced statistical technique that allows for the comparison of multiple treatments simultaneously, even if some treatments have never been directly compared in a head-to-head trial.[2] It extends traditional meta-analysis by using a network of direct and indirect evidence to estimate relative treatment effects.

filename: EMA - Time to Talk a Little Nerdy_ Network Meta-Analysis - EMA 2025 July _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: This method is particularly useful in medicine when multiple treatment options exist, by helping to rank interventions according to their effectiveness and safety.

filename: EMA - Time to Talk a Little Nerdy_ Network Meta-Analysis - EMA 2025 July _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: In a traditional pairwise meta-analysis, researchers compare only 2 treatments at a time, according to direct-evidence studies.

filename: EMA - Time to Talk a Little Nerdy_ Network Meta-Analysis - EMA 2025 July _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: However, in real-world clinical decision-making, multiple treatment options are often available for a condition, and not all of them have been directly compared in a study.

filename: EMA - Time to Talk a Little Nerdy_ Network Meta-Analysis - EMA 2025 July _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: This is where NMA can become valuable.

filename: EMA - Time to Talk a Little Nerdy_ Network Meta-Analysis - EMA 2025 July _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: How NMAs enable multiple comparisons:

filename: EMA - Time to Talk a Little Nerdy_ Network Meta-Analysis - EMA 2025 July _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: Direct comparisons

filename: EMA - Time to Talk a Little Nerdy_ Network Meta-Analysis - EMA 2025 July _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: : If 2 treatments (eg, A vs B) have been tested in RCTs, their effect sizes can be directly compared.

filename: EMA - Time to Talk a Little Nerdy_ Network Meta-Analysis - EMA 2025 July _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: Indirect comparisons : If no direct RCTs have compared 2 treatments (eg, A vs C), but both have been compared with a common comparator (B), NMA can use statistical methods to infer their relative effects (A vs C) through indirect evidence.

filename: EMA - Time to Talk a Little Nerdy_ Network Meta-Analysis - EMA 2025 July _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: Mixed evidence (direct and indirect) : When direct and indirect comparisons are available, NMA integrates both sources of evidence to increase precision.

filename: EMA - Time to Talk a Little Nerdy_ Network Meta-Analysis - EMA 2025 July _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: A key advantage of NMAs is that they not only estimate treatment effects but also rank treatments by effectiveness or safety.

filename: EMA - Time to Talk a Little Nerdy_ Network Meta-Analysis - EMA 2025 July _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: Outputs such as surface under the cumulative ranking (SUCRA) curves are provided, which can help identify the most effective or safest option.[3]

filename: EMA - Time to Talk a Little Nerdy_ Network Meta-Analysis - EMA 2025 July _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: One notable aspect of NMAs is that they require consistency in the data being incorporated.

filename: EMA - Time to Talk a Little Nerdy_ Network Meta-Analysis - EMA 2025 July _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: This consistency is different from heterogeneity in a traditional SRMA.

filename: EMA - Time to Talk a Little Nerdy_ Network Meta-Analysis - EMA 2025 July _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: Heterogeneity in SRMAs refers to differences in study characteristics, such as variations in patient populations, interventions, study designs, or outcomes measured.

filename: EMA - Time to Talk a Little Nerdy_ Network Meta-Analysis - EMA 2025 July _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: This heterogeneity occurs within direct comparisons of treatments and can lead to variability in the effect estimates from different studies.

filename: EMA - Time to Talk a Little Nerdy_ Network Meta-Analysis - EMA 2025 July _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: Inconsistency, in contrast, is a specific issue in NMAs that arises when direct and indirect evidence provides conflicting results.

filename: EMA - Time to Talk a Little Nerdy_ Network Meta-Analysis - EMA 2025 July _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: In other words, if an NMA suggests that treatment A is better than treatment B, according to direct comparisons, but indirect comparisons through a common comparator (eg, treatment C) suggest the opposite, inconsistency exists in the network.

filename: EMA - Time to Talk a Little Nerdy_ Network Meta-Analysis - EMA 2025 July _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: This inconsistency can indicate potential biases, differences in study populations, or methodological issues that must be addressed before the results can be trusted  .

filename: EMA - Time to Talk a Little Nerdy_ Network Meta-Analysis - EMA 2025 July _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: Whereas heterogeneity is a broader concept that applies to variability within studies, inconsistency is a specific challenge in NMAs that arises when different sources of evidence within the network do not align.

filename: EMA - Time to Talk a Little Nerdy_ Network Meta-Analysis - EMA 2025 July _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: Both aspects must be assessed carefully to ensure the validity of an NMA's conclusions.

filename: EMA - Time to Talk a Little Nerdy_ Network Meta-Analysis - EMA 2025 July _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: NMAs have several advantages over traditional systematic reviews and pairwise meta-analyses.

filename: EMA - Time to Talk a Little Nerdy_ Network Meta-Analysis - EMA 2025 July _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: The main benefit, which we have mentioned, is that NMAs enable simultaneous comparison of multiple treatments, even when direct head-to-head trials are lacking.

filename: EMA - Time to Talk a Little Nerdy_ Network Meta-Analysis - EMA 2025 July _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: Another key advantage is their enhanced statistical power and precision: by synthesizing evidence from a broader set of studies, NMAs often provide more reliable effect estimates and narrower confidence intervals than individual studies or pairwise meta-analyses.

filename: EMA - Time to Talk a Little Nerdy_ Network Meta-Analysis - EMA 2025 July _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: Consequently, treatment differences that might not be evident in smaller direct comparisons may be detected.

filename: EMA - Time to Talk a Little Nerdy_ Network Meta-Analysis - EMA 2025 July _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: NMAs also help rank treatments by efficacy and safety, thus providing clinicians and policymakers with clear, actionable insights.

filename: EMA - Time to Talk a Little Nerdy_ Network Meta-Analysis - EMA 2025 July _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: Instead of simply concluding whether 1 treatment is superior to another, NMAs generate rankings that can guide treatment choices according to each intervention's probability of being the most effective or safest option  .

filename: EMA - Time to Talk a Little Nerdy_ Network Meta-Analysis - EMA 2025 July _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: A fourth potential benefit is that NMAs may increase the generalizability of findings by incorporating a wider range of studies and patient populations.

filename: EMA - Time to Talk a Little Nerdy_ Network Meta-Analysis - EMA 2025 July _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: This broader evidence base can increase the results' external validity and applicability to real-world clinical practice  .

filename: EMA - Time to Talk a Little Nerdy_ Network Meta-Analysis - EMA 2025 July _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: NMAs have several limitations common to SRMAs, such as GIGO, publication bias, and selection bias.

filename: EMA - Time to Talk a Little Nerdy_ Network Meta-Analysis - EMA 2025 July _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: A specific major limitation of the NMA study design is the requirement for transitivity,[4] in which all treatments being compared must be sufficiently similar across the included studies.

filename: EMA - Time to Talk a Little Nerdy_ Network Meta-Analysis - EMA 2025 July _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: If the patient populations, study designs, or outcome measures substantially differ among trials, the indirect comparisons made in an NMA may be biased or misleading  .

filename: EMA - Time to Talk a Little Nerdy_ Network Meta-Analysis - EMA 2025 July _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: Another challenge is inconsistency, which occurs when direct and indirect evidence lead to conflicting conclusions.

filename: EMA - Time to Talk a Little Nerdy_ Network Meta-Analysis - EMA 2025 July _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: If studies comparing treatment A vs treatment B yield different results from

filename: EMA - Time to Talk a Little Nerdy_ Network Meta-Analysis - EMA 2025 July _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: those inferred from indirect comparisons via treatment C, methodological differences, biases, or unmeasured confounders may be affecting the network

filename: EMA - Time to Talk a Little Nerdy_ Network Meta-Analysis - EMA 2025 July _ EM_RAP.pdf
EMA - Time to Talk a Little Nerdy_ Network Meta-Analysis - EMA 2025 July _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: Statistical complexity is another major barrier.

filename: EMA - Time to Talk a Little Nerdy_ Network Meta-Analysis - EMA 2025 July _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: Conducting and interpreting an NMA requires advanced modeling techniques, assumptions about treatment relationships, and careful handling of heterogeneity.

filename: EMA - Time to Talk a Little Nerdy_ Network Meta-Analysis - EMA 2025 July _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: Many clinicians and policymakers may find NMAs difficult to interpret without expert guidance  .

filename: EMA - Time to Talk a Little Nerdy_ Network Meta-Analysis - EMA 2025 July _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: In January, Mike and Sanjay covered 2 NMAs.

filename: EMA - Time to Talk a Little Nerdy_ Network Meta-Analysis - EMA 2025 July _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: The first was Paper #5: 'Short-Term Dual Therapy or Monotherapy with Acetaminophen and Ibuprofen for Fever: a Network Meta-Analysis

filename: EMA - Time to Talk a Little Nerdy_ Network Meta-Analysis - EMA 2025 July _ EM_RAP.pdf
EMA - Time to Talk a Little Nerdy_ Network Meta-Analysis - EMA 2025 July _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: ' [5] The authors of this NMA aimed to evaluate the comparative efficacy and safety of acetaminophen, ibuprofen, and dual therapy (combined or alternating) in decreasing discomfort and temperature in children with fever with a presumed infectious origin

filename: EMA - Time to Talk a Little Nerdy_ Network Meta-Analysis - EMA 2025 July _ EM_RAP.pdf
EMA - Time to Talk a Little Nerdy_ Network Meta-Analysis - EMA 2025 July _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: Combined acetaminophen/NSAID therapy was superior to alternating therapy, which in turn was superior to high-dose ibuprofen, which in turn was superior to acetaminophen alone.

filename: EMA - Time to Talk a Little Nerdy_ Network Meta-Analysis - EMA 2025 July _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: NMA was an appropriate methodological choice for this topic, because a standard pairwise SRMA would have enabled direct comparisons between only 2 treatments at a time, whereas the NMA allowed for both direct and indirect comparisons.

filename: EMA - Time to Talk a Little Nerdy_ Network Meta-Analysis - EMA 2025 July _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: The NMA also generated a ranking of treatment efficacy to help clinicians choose the best option  .

filename: EMA - Time to Talk a Little Nerdy_ Network Meta-Analysis - EMA 2025 July _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: Until next month, stay nerdy!

sentence: The ED can be a stressful and anxiety-provoking place, particularly for young children with a history of anxiety.

filename: EMA - Abstract 19_ Therapy Dogs for Anxiety in Children in the Emergency Department - EMA 2025 June _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: To improve child and parental experiences, pediatric EDs often employ certified child-life specialists to help mitigate children's fear and anxiety, by using play therapy, visual and auditory distractions, and other situationally appropriate techniques at developmentally appropriate levels.

filename: EMA - Abstract 19_ Therapy Dogs for Anxiety in Children in the Emergency Department - EMA 2025 June _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: This single-center, randomized clinical trial evaluated the effectiveness of usual care from a child-life specialist plus approximately 10 minutes with a therapy dog and handler, compared with care from a child-life specialist alone, on the patient-reported outcome of anxiety.

sentence: In November, we introduced the Sudbury Vertigo Risk score, a scheme for helping clinicians differentiate patients with serious central nervous system causes of vertigo from patients without serious diagnoses.

filename: EMA - Abstract 2_ Validating the Sudbury Vertigo Risk Score - EMA 2025 June _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: The score, which was derived from 3 Canadian emergency departments between 2019 and 2022, comprises 3 domains: (1) stroke risk factors, including male sex, age >65 years, and diabetes (all 1 point), or hypertension (3 points); (2) any neurologic deficits (motor/sensory; 5 points) or cerebellar signs (6 points); and (3) a benign paroxysmal positional vertigo diagnosis in the ED ( -5 points).

filename: EMA - Abstract 2_ Validating the Sudbury Vertigo Risk Score - EMA 2025 June _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: In the original derivation, a score <5 had 100% sensitivity in ruling out serious disease and approximately 70% specificity.

sentence: The chart-review methods, as reported, followed best practices, including explicit training of abstractors and measures of interrater reliability.

filename: EMA - Abstract 16_ The INSPIRE 3 Skin and Soft Tissue Randomized Clinical Trial - EMA 2025 July _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: Hospitals were randomized to either (1) routine stewardship, including updated hospital guidelines, prospective feedback to deescalate antibiotic use, requiring physicians to enter the reason for antibiotic choice, and other asynchronous educational efforts; or (2) a complex computerized physician order entry (CPOE) bundle intervention.

filename: EMA - Abstract 16_ The INSPIRE 3 Skin and Soft Tissue Randomized Clinical Trial - EMA 2025 July _ EM_RAP.pdf

filename: EMA - Time to Talk a Little Nerdy_ Burden of Proof - EMA 2025 June _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: This month Ken and Swami discuss how citation errors, occurring at rates of 11-15% in biomedical literature, propagate false information and create "academic urban legends." They provide compelling examples, including the spinach iron myth and opioid addiction misconceptions, while explaining how these errors undermine scientific integrity.

filename: EMA - Time to Talk a Little Nerdy_ Burden of Proof - EMA 2025 June _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: Time to Talk a Little Nerdy

filename: EMA - Time to Talk a Little Nerdy_ Burden of Proof - EMA 2025 June _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: Burden of Proof

filename: EMA - Time to Talk a Little Nerdy_ Burden of Proof - EMA 2025 June _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: Today, we are dropping into an important issue in the medical literature: inaccurate citations and the burden of proof.

filename: EMA - Time to Talk a Little Nerdy_ Burden of Proof - EMA 2025 June _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: We were spurred to tackle this topic after reading an article by Peoples and colleagues in the BMJ in 2023.[i]

filename: EMA - Time to Talk a Little Nerdy_ Burden of Proof - EMA 2025 June _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: The title of the article is 'Burden of Proof: Combating Inaccurate Citations in Biomedical Literature . '

filename: EMA - Time to Talk a Little Nerdy_ Burden of Proof - EMA 2025 June _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: We often need to remind listeners that anyone making a claim has the burden of supporting the position with evidence.

filename: EMA - Time to Talk a Little Nerdy_ Burden of Proof - EMA 2025 June _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: It is not called a burden because it is easy, and shifting the burden of proof onto another person is a logical fallacy.

filename: EMA - Time to Talk a Little Nerdy_ Burden of Proof - EMA 2025 June _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: The premise of the article is that authors often cite literature to support a claim, yet the cited literature does not support the statement or claim.

filename: EMA - Time to Talk a Little Nerdy_ Burden of Proof - EMA 2025 June _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: Obviously, we see this as a problem, but Peoples and colleagues point out 2 main reasons why we need to pay attention to citation errors:

filename: EMA - Time to Talk a Little Nerdy_ Burden of Proof - EMA 2025 June _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: Propagation of false or misinterpreted data: Inaccurate citations can lead to the spread of incorrect or misinterpreted data, which can create "academic urban legends." As a result, the publication of accurate findings may be delayed, and incorrect ideas can be treated as facts.

filename: EMA - Time to Talk a Little Nerdy_ Burden of Proof - EMA 2025 June _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: Undermining the integrity of scientific literature review : The widespread presence of citation errors weakens trust in the process of literature review and reduces it to a "box-ticking exercise." This lack of trust diminishes the quality of scholarly work, and makes the background and discussion sections of articles less valuable.

filename: EMA - Time to Talk a Little Nerdy_ Burden of Proof - EMA 2025 June _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: Additionally, it encourages sloppy research practices among young investigators and trainees, and further perpetuates the cycle of poor citation practices.

filename: EMA - Time to Talk a Little Nerdy_ Burden of Proof - EMA 2025 June _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: A great example of an academic urban legend is the classic teaching that when a posterior nasal pack is placed for epistaxis, patients must be closely monitored, because they are at risk of severe bradycardia.

filename: EMA - Time to Talk a Little Nerdy_ Burden of Proof - EMA 2025 June _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: Yet, when we trace this claim back, every article cites a 1971 publication as the source of the information, but that article does not even contain the word 'bradycardia.' After an extensive search with a medical librarian, we could not find an iota of data supporting this phenomenon.

filename: EMA - Time to Talk a Little Nerdy_ Burden of Proof - EMA 2025 June _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: Peoples and colleagues discuss the misrepresentation of a 1980 New England Journal of Medicine letter on the risk of opioid addiction.

filename: EMA - Time to Talk a Little Nerdy_ Burden of Proof - EMA 2025 June _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: The letter, written by Porter and Jick, stated that addiction was rare in patients treated with narcotics.[ii] However, this brief statement was widely misquoted and misrepresented in the medical literature over time.

filename: EMA - Time to Talk a Little Nerdy_ Burden of Proof - EMA 2025 June _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: Research by Leung[iii] et al documents how the original statement was distorted through inaccurate citation.

filename: EMA - Time to Talk a Little Nerdy_ Burden of Proof - EMA 2025 June _ EM_RAP.pdf

sentence: The citation-error rates in the biomedical literature range from 11% to 15%, whereas in the general scientific literature, as many as 25% of citations may be inaccurate.

sentence: 20% were chains of inaccurate citations copied from one article to another

sentence: The article describes how an academic myth about the high iron content of spinach persisted for decades because of inaccurate citations.

filename: EMA - Time to Talk a Little Nerdy_ Burden of Proof - EMA 2025 June _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: In 1981, Hamblin published an article titled 'Fake!' in which he attempted to debunk a common misconception regarding the iron content of spinach.[iv] However, unbeknownst to him, the information that he used was itself incorrect.

filename: EMA - Time to Talk a Little Nerdy_ Burden of Proof - EMA 2025 June _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: Other authors subsequently cited his work, often without verifying the original source, and his statements became increasingly distorted over time.

filename: EMA - Time to Talk a Little Nerdy_ Burden of Proof - EMA 2025 June _ EM_RAP.pdf

filename: EMA - Time to Talk a Little Nerdy_ Burden of Proof - EMA 2025 June _ EM_RAP.pdf

filename: EMA - Time to Talk a Little Nerdy_ Burden of Proof - EMA 2025 June _ EM_RAP.pdf

filename: EMA - Time to Talk a Little Nerdy_ Burden of Proof - EMA 2025 June _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: Among the reasons listed for citation errors in the biomedical literature, 3 important ones, according to their potential impact on scientific integrity and knowledge dissemination, are as follows:

filename: EMA - Time to Talk a Little Nerdy_ Burden of Proof - EMA 2025 June _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: Misinterpretation : Incorrectly summarizing or understanding a source can distort scientific conclusions and propagate misinformation.

filename: EMA - Time to Talk a Little Nerdy_ Burden of Proof - EMA 2025 June _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: This distortion is particularly dangerous because it can lead to false medical guidelines or treatment recommendations.

filename: EMA - Time to Talk a Little Nerdy_ Burden of Proof - EMA 2025 June _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: Hallucinatory citations : The rise of AI-generated citations that do not exist or misrepresent actual data presents a growing risk.

filename: EMA - Time to Talk a Little Nerdy_ Burden of Proof - EMA 2025 June _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: If unchecked, the spread of misinformation in the scientific literature could accelerate at an unprecedented scale.

filename: EMA - Time to Talk a Little Nerdy_ Burden of Proof - EMA 2025 June _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: Lazy author syndrome : When authors cite references without reading them in full, errors accumulate and spread.

filename: EMA - Time to Talk a Little Nerdy_ Burden of Proof - EMA 2025 June _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: A " copy-paste" culture can result, in which inaccurate claims become widely accepted simply because they are frequently cited.

filename: EMA - Time to Talk a Little Nerdy_ Burden of Proof - EMA 2025 June _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: One error that we commonly see is secondary citation, in which an author refers to a review article without pulling the original data.

filename: EMA - Time to Talk a Little Nerdy_ Burden of Proof - EMA 2025 June _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: This effect can snowball as the article is continually cited, but no one ever pulls the original data to review.

filename: EMA - Time to Talk a Little Nerdy_ Burden of Proof - EMA 2025 June _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: This is an excellent reason why we often encourage readers to go back to the primary source to confirm its validity.

filename: EMA - Time to Talk a Little Nerdy_ Burden of Proof - EMA 2025 June _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: To fix the situation, it seems that readers would need to pull and review every article cited to make sure the authors' claims are accurate.

filename: EMA - Time to Talk a Little Nerdy_ Burden of Proof - EMA 2025 June _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: This, of course, would be massively time-consuming and impossible to do.

filename: EMA - Time to Talk a Little Nerdy_ Burden of Proof - EMA 2025 June _ EM_RAP.pdf

filename: EMA - Abstract 3_ GFAP and UCH-L1 as Predictors of Brain Injury After Mild TBI - EMA 2025 July _ EM_RAP.pdf
sentence: The authors of this article followed the Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses guidelines to identify published studies in adults with mild head injury who underwent measurement of glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP) and/or ubiquitin carboxy-terminal hydrolase L1 (UCH-L1), and received head CT.

filename: EMA - Abstract 3_ GFAP and UCH-L1 as Predictors of Brain Injury After Mild TBI - EMA 2025 July _ EM_RAP.pdf

sentence: The data were extracted by 2 authors and verified by a third author.

sentence: Of the 16 articles identified for inclusion, 14 reported prospective studies.

filename: EMA - Abstract 3_ GFAP and UCH-L1 as Predictors of Brain Injury After Mild TBI - EMA 2025 July _ EM_RAP.pdf

filename: EMA - Abstract 3_ GFAP and UCH-L1 as Predictors of Brain Injury After Mild TBI - EMA 2025 July _ EM_RAP.pdf

filename: EMA - Abstract 3_ GFAP and UCH-L1 as Predictors of Brain Injury After Mild TBI - EMA 2025 July _ EM_RAP.pdf

sentence: The overall pooled sensitivity and specificity for a combination of GFAP and UCH-L1 were 100% (95% CI, 99%-100%) and 31% (95% CI, 26% to 36%), respectively, and the NPV was 100% (95% CI, 100%-100%).
